entry.title: Deploying SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) on AWS Free Tier Using Terraform + Ansible + SLES
entry.content:
I‚Äôve spent a bit of time experimenting with Cloud Connectors recently and wanted a faster, cleaner way to spin one up without all the usual hassle. In this post, I build on the earlier SCC and Ansible write-ups and bring everything together into a single workflow. We‚Äôll automate the entire deployment using Terraform for provisioning and Ansible for configuration, resulting in a fully working SCC with minimal manual effort.

This guide provides a fully working, fully automated setup using:

  • Terraform for provisioning the EC2 instance
  • Ansible for OS prep and SCC installation
  • Heap tuning via props.ini for stable SCC operation

1. Directory layout

sap-lab/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ run.sh
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ run_destroy.sh
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ terraform/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.tf
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ variables.tf
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ terraform.tfvars
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ <KEYPAIR_NAME>.pub
‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ansible/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ site.yml
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ inventory.ini
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ansible.cfg
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ roles/
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sap_prep/
        ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tasks/main.yml
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ sap_scc/
            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ defaults/main.yml
            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tasks/main.yml
            ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ templates/scc_daemon.service.j2

2. Terraform: main.tf

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.5"
  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }
}

provider "aws" {
  region = var.region
}

resource "aws_security_group" "sap_scc_sg" {
  name        = "sap-scc-sg"
  description = "Allow SCC UI and SSH"
  vpc_id      = var.vpc_id

  ingress {
    from_port   = 22
    to_port     = 22
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  ingress {
    from_port   = 8443
    to_port     = 8443
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  egress {
    from_port   = 0
    to_port     = 0
    protocol    = "-1"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }
}

resource "aws_instance" "sap_scc" {
  ami           = var.sles_ami
  instance_type = "t2.micro"
  key_name      = var.keypair_name

  subnet_id                   = var.subnet_id
  associate_public_ip_address = true
  vpc_security_group_ids      = [aws_security_group.sap_scc_sg.id]

  tags = {
    Name = "SAP-LAB-SCC"
  }
}

output "ansible_inventory" {
  value = "sap_host ansible_host=${aws_instance.sap_scc.public_ip} ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=../terraform/${var.private_key} ansible_ssh_common_args='-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null'"
}

3. Terraform Variables (variables.tf)

variable "region" {}
variable "vpc_id" {}
variable "subnet_id" {}
variable "keypair_name" {}
variable "private_key" {}
variable "sles_ami" {}

4. terraform.tfvars

region       = "us-east-2"
vpc_id       = "vpc-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"
subnet_id    = "subnet-xxxxxxxxxxxx"
keypair_name = "my-keypair"
private_key  = "my-keypair.pem"
sles_ami     = "ami-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"

5. Ansible config (ansible.cfg)

[defaults]
host_key_checking = False
retry_files_enabled = False

6. Role: OS Preparation (sap_prep/tasks/main.yml)

---
- name: Install prerequisites
  zypper:
    name:
      - wget
      - net-tools
      - chrony
      - unzip
      - curl
    state: present

- name: Ensure chronyd is running
  service:
    name: chronyd
    state: started
    enabled: yes

- name: Set vm.swappiness
  ansible.posix.sysctl:
    name: vm.swappiness
    value: "10"
    state: present
    reload: yes

7. SCC Role Defaults (sap_scc/defaults/main.yml)

---
scc_version: "2.16.2"
scc_file: "sapcc-{{ scc_version }}-linux-x64.zip"

scc_install_dir: /opt/sap/scc
scc_user: sccadm
scc_group: sccadm

scc_jvm_xms: "256m"
scc_jvm_xmx: "512m"

scc_service_name: scc_daemon

8. SCC Installation Tasks (sap_scc/tasks/main.yml)

---
- name: Ensure sccadm group exists
  group:
    name: "{{ scc_group }}"
    system: yes

- name: Ensure sccadm user exists
  user:
    name: "{{ scc_user }}"
    group: "{{ scc_group }}"
    shell: /sbin/nologin
    system: yes

- name: Install prerequisites
  become: yes
  zypper:
    name:
      - unzip
      - curl
      - java-17-openjdk-headless
    state: present

- name: Create installer directory
  file:
    path: /tmp/scc-installer
    state: directory

- name: Upload SCC ZIP (2.16.2)
  copy:
    src: sapcc-2.16.2-linux-x64.zip
    dest: /tmp/scc-installer/sapcc.zip

- name: Extract SCC ZIP
  unarchive:
    src: /tmp/scc-installer/sapcc.zip
    dest: /tmp/scc-installer
    remote_src: yes

- name: Locate SCC RPM
  find:
    paths: /tmp/scc-installer
    patterns: "com.sap.scc-ui-*.rpm"
  register: rpm_file

- name: Fail if SCC RPM not found
  fail:
    msg: "SCC RPM not found."
  when: rpm_file.matched == 0

- name: Install SCC RPM
  become: yes
  zypper:
    name: "{{ rpm_file.files[0].path }}"
    disable_gpg_check: yes
    state: present

# Heap tuning
- name: Tune Xms
  become: yes
  replace:
    path: /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
    regexp: '-Xms[0-9]+m'
    replace: "-Xms{{ scc_jvm_xms }}"

- name: Tune Xmx
  become: yes
  replace:
    path: /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
    regexp: '-Xmx[0-9]+m'
    replace: "-Xmx{{ scc_jvm_xmx }}"

- name: Tune NewSize
  become: yes
  replace:
    path: /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
    regexp: 'NewSize=[0-9]+m'
    replace: 'NewSize=256m'

- name: Tune MaxNewSize
  become: yes
  replace:
    path: /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
    regexp: 'MaxNewSize=[0-9]+m'
    replace: 'MaxNewSize=256m'

- name: Enable SCC daemon
  become: yes
  systemd:
    name: "{{ scc_service_name }}"
    enabled: yes

- name: Start SCC daemon
  become: yes
  systemd:
    name: "{{ scc_service_name }}"
    state: restarted

9. Systemd Template (scc_daemon.service.j2)

[Unit]
Description=SAP Cloud Connector
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=forking
User={{ scc_user }}
Group={{ scc_group }}
ExecStart=/opt/sap/scc/go.sh -start
ExecStop=/opt/sap/scc/go.sh -stop
Restart=on-failure

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

10. site.yml

---
- hosts: sap_hosts
  become: true
  roles:
    - sap_prep
    - sap_scc

11. run.sh

#!/bin/bash
set -e

cd terraform
terraform init
terraform apply -auto-approve

INVENTORY=$(terraform output -raw ansible_inventory)

cd ../ansible
echo "[sap_hosts]" > inventory.ini
echo "$INVENTORY" >> inventory.ini

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml

Output (from ansible):

Outputs:

public_ip = "<PUBLIC_IP>"

PLAY [sap_hosts] *************************************************************************************************************

TASK [Gathering Facts] *******************************************************************************************************
[WARNING]: Host 'ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>' is using the discovered Python interpreter at '/usr/bin/python3.13', but future installation of another Python interpreter could cause a different interpreter to be discovered. See https://docs.ansible.com/ansible-core/2.19/reference_appendices/interpreter_discovery.html for more information.
[WARNING]: sftp transfer mechanism failed on [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]. Use ANSIBLE_DEBUG=1 to see detailed information
[WARNING]: scp transfer mechanism failed on [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]. Use ANSIBLE_DEBUG=1 to see detailed information
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Install base packages] **************************************************************************************
changed: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Start chronyd] **********************************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Refresh SUSE repos] *****************************************************************************************
changed: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Install Java 17 (OpenJDK)] **********************************************************************************
changed: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Verify Java installation] ***********************************************************************************
changed: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Ensure sccadm group exists] **********************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Ensure sccadm user exists] ***********************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Install prerequisites] ***************************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Create installer directory] **********************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Upload SCC ZIP (2.16.2)] *************************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Extract SCC ZIP] *********************************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Find SCC RPM inside extracted ZIP] ***************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Fail if SCC RPM not found] ***********************************************************************************
skipping: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Install SCC RPM with zypper] *********************************************************************************
changed: [ec

12. Once the SAP Cloud Connector service has started on your SUSE instance, open the administration UI in your browser.

https://<YOUR_PUBLIC_IP>:8443


 From here you can change the default password and connect the SCC up to BTP / on-prem etc.

13. run_destroy.sh

#!/bin/bash
set -e

cd terraform
terraform destroy -auto-approve
cd ..

echo "# destroyed" > ansible/inventory.ini

Conclusion

Fully automated provisioning and configuration of SAP Cloud Connector on SLES using Terraform and Ansible, with JVM tuning for AWS Free Tier.

entry.title: Expose SAP CPI Integration Flows as APIs Using SAP API Management: A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite empowers businesses to integrate applications and processes efficiently. One powerful capability is exposing CPI integration flows as APIs via API Management (APIM). This enables centralized governance, security, and monitoring of APIs. In this blog, we‚Äôll cover the step-by-step process to achieve this.

Step 1: Set Up SAP Process Integration Runtime

Navigate to SAP BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount ‚Üí Instances & Subscriptions.

  • Create Service Instance
    • Service: SAP Process Integration Runtime
    • Plan: api
    • Instance Name: e.g. CPI_API_Instance
    • Assign all roles (except security roles)Create Service Key

      Click the ‚ãÆ (three-dot menu) ‚Üí Create Service Key ‚Üí Save credentials (Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL).

Step 2: Design & Deploy a Sample iFlow

In Integration Suite:

  • Create Package:
    Navigate to Design ‚Üí Integrations & APIs ‚Üí Create Package (e.g. Demo_API_Package).

  • Build iFlow:
    Add an HTTP Sender and a Content Modifier (set sample body content).
    Deploy the iFlow.

 

 

 

Step 3: Configure API Provider with OAuth2

In API Management:

  • Create API Provider:
    Navigate to Configure ‚Üí API Providers ‚Üí Create New.
    • Name: CPI_Provider
    • Connection Type: Cloud Integration
    • Host: Use host from Service Key
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Client Credentials
      • Enter Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL

 

Step 4: Create & Deploy API Proxy

  • Create API Proxy:
    Select the API Provider ‚Üí Click Discover ‚Üí Choose deployed iFlow.
    Enable OAuth and provide credentials.
    • Proxy Name: flow-api-proxy
    • Save & Deploy.

 

Step 5: Test Your API

Use Postman:

  • Paste the Proxy URL
  • Send a request
  • Confirm the response from your iFlow.

 

Conclusion

By exposing SAP CPI integration flows as managed APIs through SAP API Management, you create a robust integration layer that blends flexibility with strong governance. This approach offers several key benefits:

  • Centralized Control: Manage all APIs from a single platform, making lifecycle management simple and efficient.
  • Enhanced Security: Protect your integrations with OAuth2 and other security policies to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Scalability & Reusability: Reuse APIs across multiple applications and business processes, cutting down development time and effort.
  • Comprehensive Monitoring: Gain full visibility into API performance and usage with built-in analytics and dashboards.

This setup not only streamlines integration but also supports modern API-driven architectures, enabling faster innovation and better interoperability across your enterprise. As a next step, consider adding features like rate limiting, caching, and custom policies in API Management to further boost performance and security.

entry.title: The Art of Possible: Why Now Is the Time for SAP Sales and Service AI Agents in Customer Experience
entry.content:
Estimated reading time ‚âà 9‚Äì10 minutes

1. Why AI Agents in CX Now?

The timing for AI agents in customer experience couldn‚Äôt be better. We‚Äôve reached the point where rising customer expectations, the need for rapid decisions, the demand for scalable personalization, and the evolution of AI have all converged.

Together, they‚Äôre transforming how sales and service teams deliver value‚Äîand how customers experience every interaction.

Rising Customer Expectations Are Raising the Stakes

Today‚Äôs customers expect instant, effortless experiences across every touchpoint. And when they don‚Äôt get them, they leave.

  • 59% of customers abandon a brand after two negative service experiences
  • 76% of customers expect companies to understand their needs and preferences.
  • 57% of customers prefer engaging with automated systems for simple inquiries. (Source)

Traditional customer service models can‚Äôt keep up with this level of demand. AI agents can‚Äîby responding instantly, understanding customer intent, and routing issues to the right place the first time.

The Speed of Business Demands Faster Decisions

Business moves at lightning speed, and slow responses can cost revenue and reputation.

AI agents excel in fast-moving environments. They can read and process unstructured data‚Äîlike emails, chat logs, and support tickets‚Äîand turn it into actionable insights in seconds.

While human agents need time to research and analyse, AI agents can instantly access customer history, identify patterns, and make data-driven decisions in real time.

Scalable Personalization Is No Longer Optional

Customers want more than good service‚Äîthey want service that feels personal. But delivering that at scale is beyond what traditional systems can do.

With Generative AI, personalization becomes effortless. AI agents can analyse massive datasets to create tailored recommendations, custom messages, and proactive support for every individual‚Äîacross every channel, and without adding headcount.

AI Is the New Assistant for Sales & Service Teams

We‚Äôve moved far beyond basic chatbots. Today‚Äôs AI agents act as intelligent assistants, transforming how teams work and how customers interact.

They can:

  • Streamline daily operations
  • Handle complex transactions (like billing or payment extensions)
  • Maintain accuracy and compliance
  • Work 24/7, without fatigue

For human teams, that means less manual effort and more time focused on building relationships and solving complex problems that require empathy and creativity.

The Bottom Line

AI agents are no longer a futuristic idea‚Äîthey‚Äôre a business necessity.

They bring together speed, personalization, and intelligence to deliver exceptional customer experiences at scale.

The question isn‚Äôt if your organization should embrace AI agents. It‚Äôs how quickly you can start.

 

2. What is the SAP CX AI Toolkit?

The SAP CX AI Toolkit brings together embedded generative and predictive AI to deliver intelligent automation and smarter customer experiences. This cloud-native solution integrates directly into SAP CX systems, enabling businesses to automate case categorization, inquiry routing, and unstructured data processing for faster, more accurate outcomes.

Generative AI personalizes content, summaries, and recommendations, while predictive AI anticipates customer behaviour to drive proactive engagement. With capabilities like visual search, AI-powered product tagging, and role-specific insights across Sales, Service, Commerce, and the Customer Data Platform, the toolkit connects data and intelligence to create seamless, personalized interactions at every touchpoint.

 

3. The Agent Concept ‚Äî From Tasks to Outcomes?

The CX AI Toolkit represents a fundamental shift from traditional AI that merely suggests to intelligent agents that execute, automate, and guide across complete business processes in both Sales & Service V1 and V2 environments.

Agents That Execute Real Actions

Unlike conventional AI tools that provide recommendations requiring human action, CX AI agents directly execute business processes. When a customer service ticket arrives, the Classification Agent handles smart categorization and instant routing based on business rules - it doesn't just suggest a category, it automatically assigns it and routes the case to the appropriate team. The Knowledge Agent not only documents the solution but intelligently captures customer needs and usage patterns, creating structured knowledge articles and publishing them directly to your knowledge base.

Comprehensive Process Automation

These agents work together to automate complex repetitive tasks with contextual understanding. The Q&A Agent automatically searches the knowledge base and matches solutions, while simultaneously providing immediate answers to product or upgrade questions. This creates a seamless flow where AI agents can process large volumes of data to identify patterns and trends that might be overlooked by human analysis, enabling end-to-end automation rather than isolated task assistance.

Intelligent Guidance Across V1 and V2 Environments

The toolkit adapts its guidance capabilities based on the specific SAP environment:

Sales & Service Cloud V2 supports comprehensive contextual behaviours where agents work by matching the tool to the entity in focus. When you open a Service Case, the AI Tool will read the case that is currently open and will pre-fill that case for you in the AI Tool. The system maintains awareness of your workflow, with recently viewed cases appearing as suggestions during searches.

Sales Cloud V1 offers additional capabilities like the Quote Creation Agent, though this functionality is confirmed to be supported only for Sales Cloud V1 and there is no confirmed roadmap for support in Sales Cloud V2.

Process-Wide Intelligence

What sets these agents apart is their ability to maintain all the context and customer intelligence throughout the journey, while automating the time-consuming tasks. They don't just execute individual steps - they orchestrate entire workflows. For example, when a service case is resolved, the same intelligence that helped with classification and resolution now provides immediate answers to any product or upgrade questions included in the opportunity notes, ensuring no context is lost in handoffs between teams.

Ready-to-Deploy Automation

These agents are delivered through the CX AI Toolkit and work out of the box with SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud, requiring no custom development. Organizations can configure specialized AI agents that perform complex business tasks with no coding required, achieving 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks and 50% productivity boost in service teams .

The CX AI Toolkit transforms AI from a suggestion engine into an active participant in your business processes, executing tasks, automating workflows, and providing intelligent guidance that adapts to your specific SAP environment and business context.

 

4. Key Agents for Sales and Service Cloud

Agents suitable for both of Sales and Service Cloud

Q&A Agent

The Q&A Agent processes natural language questions and delivers accurate responses by searching knowledge bases and matching solutions. Key capabilities include:

  • Processes natural language questions and delivers accurate responses
  • Allows administrators to define specific questions answered using custom data sources, tickets, or cases
  • Provides 50% higher sales staff productivity for agent-handled tasks
  • Instant access to the most experienced agent's knowledge
  • Works with both Sales / Service Cloud V1 and V2

Knowledge Creation Agent

The Knowledge Creation Agent analyses new tickets or cases and automatically creates Knowledge Base Articles (KBA) that are published back to the source. Key capabilities include:

  • Analyses new tickets or cases and creates Knowledge Base Articles (KBA)
  • Publishes articles back to the source ticket or case
  • Increases sales staff productivity by focusing on high-value customer interactions 
  • Intelligent documentation of solutions and customer usage patterns
  • Increased focus on high-value customer interactions
  • Improved customer satisfaction through better knowledge capture
  • 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks

Sales Cloud Agent

Quote Creation Agent  

The Quote Creation Agent is designed to streamline the quote generation process. Key capabilities include:

  • Automates quote generation by monitoring Microsoft Office 365 shared mailboxes
  • Transforms incoming email requests into ready-to-send quotes
  • Increases sales efficiency and drives revenue growth by eliminating manual, repetitive work
  • Important limitation: Currently supported only for Sales Cloud V1, with no confirmed roadmap for Sales Cloud V2 support

Service Cloud Agent

Case Classification Agent

The Case Classification Agent analyses new customer service tickets and automatically classifies them based on company business requirements. This agent provides:

  • Smart categorization and instant routing based on business rules
  • Elimination of manual classification work that typically consumes valuable agent time
  • 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks
  • Greater operational performance across service processes

5. The ‚ÄúArt of Possible‚Äù: From Classification to Knowledge Creation

It‚Äôs 3 PM on a Friday afternoon at MedTech Solutions, and Dr. Martinez, a senior support specialist, receives a new support ticket:

‚ÄúOur new imaging software keeps freezing during patient scans, causing delays in our radiology department. We‚Äôve tried restarting, but the issue persists during high-resolution scans.‚Äù

For most teams, this would mark the start of a long weekend challenge‚Äîmanual triage, frantic back-and-forths, and lost time. This is where our AI Agents step into action.

The Classification Agent in Action

Within seconds, the Classification Agent gets to work. It scans the ticket, picking up on terms like ‚Äúimaging software,‚Äù ‚Äúfreezing,‚Äù ‚Äúpatient scans,‚Äù and ‚Äúradiology.‚Äù

Instead of waiting for a human to assign it, the AI instantly tags it as a Critical Software Issue and routes it directly to the Medical Software Support team with Priority 1 status.

No delays. No confusion. Just precision routing‚Äîpowered by AI that understands the business context and works 24/7 like a digital triage expert.

The Intelligent Handoff

The ticket appears in Dr. Martinez‚Äôs queue, already enriched with context and suggested similar cases. The system‚Äôs recommendations immediately point her toward a known pattern‚Äîhigh-resolution scans causing memory strain.

With insights at her fingertips, she diagnoses the problem as a memory allocation issue and resolves it by fine-tuning the software‚Äôs buffer settings. The radiology department is back online in minutes, not hours.

The Knowledge Creation Agent Steps In

As Dr. Martinez documents her fix, the Knowledge Creation Agent automatically analyses the resolution details. Recognizing a recurring pattern, it generates a new Knowledge Base Article (KBA) titled:

‚ÄúResolving Memory Allocation Issues in High-Resolution Medical Imaging Software.‚Äù

The article is structured, formatted, and published‚Äîready for future reference by both customers and support teams.

What once required hours of manual work‚Äîclassification, resolution, documentation‚Äîhas now become a continuous learning loop powered by intelligent automation.

The Art of Possible

In this single interaction, the CX AI Toolkit transformed a complex support challenge into a self-improving process:

  • The Classification Agent ensured the ticket reached the right expert immediately.
  • The Knowledge Creation Agent turned the solution into reusable knowledge.
  • And Dr. Martinez? She focused on solving problems, not managing workflows.

This is the Art of the Possible‚Äîwhere AI doesn‚Äôt just assist but learns, acts, and teaches, creating a smarter, faster, and more connected customer experience.

To explore the Art of possible in real life, check out one of our favourite customer stories from Bosch and see how AI is optimizing business and boosting efficiency.


 

6. Architecture

In the following diagram discover our architecture in which all of enterprise data is flowing from different data sources (SAP, Microsoft or Custom ones) into a secure foundation (more details in the section 7. Governance & Trust). AI Services transform this data into intelligence through search, reasoning and orchestration. This intelligence powers the CX AI Toolkit, where tools for content creation, Q&A, intelligent search, and even custom AI agents come together.

Finally, these capabilities appear wherever teams work‚Äîinside the web application, a Chrome extension, or fully embedded experiences‚Äîbringing AI directly into every sales and service moment.

 

7. Governance & Trust

 The SAP CX AI Toolkit operates through a six-step Trusted AI Layer that ensures secure and ethical AI processing:

  1. Secure Data Retrieval: Adheres to SAP's best practices, ensuring only relevant data is accessible through user credentials when pulling information from connected systems
  2. SAP Context Grounding: Utilizes Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) concepts to enrich GenAI prompts with comprehensive ancillary information surrounding data objects to enhance output quality
  3. Obfuscation and Bias Prevention: Implements robust obfuscation techniques, hashing all identifiable information and replacing it with temporary placeholders across all fields. This process also aids in bias prevention by filtering out sensitive attributes like gender or nationality
  4. Zero Data Retention: Ensures all data transmitted to LLM services is securely deleted after each transaction, significantly reducing the risk of proprietary data exposure
  5. Audit Logs: Maintains rigorous audit logs aligned with SAP guidelines, providing Trace IDs for error tracking
  6. Human in the Loop: Emphasizes preventing automatic data dissemination without validation, acknowledging that GenAI outputs require human oversight

SAP ensures transparency through:

  • Documentation and UI Indicators: Clear marking of AI systems and effective communication of their capabilities and limitations
  • Post-hoc Explanation Tools: Implementation of tools like SHAP and LIME for explainable AI
  • Traceable Systems: All AI systems must be traceable and transparent in their operations

Users maintain full transparency and control over their data through:

  • Centralized Dashboard: Full transparency and control over data through a central dashboard
  • Anonymized Data Processing: Customer data combines accuracy with uncompromised security through anonymization
  • No Third-Party Training: SAP does not share customer data with external vendors for model training

Governance Structure

SAP's responsible AI implementation includes:

  • Global AI Ethics Steering Committee: Senior SAP leaders reviewing approach, processes, and product capabilities
  • AI Ethics Advisory Panel: Additional governance body ensuring ethical compliance
  • Regular Review Processes: Continuous evaluation and updates of ethical guidelines

SAP's approach to responsible AI is built on a comprehensive framework that ensures ethical, secure, and compliant AI development and deployment across all business applications. The company has established itself as a leader in responsible AI practices through rigorous governance structures and adherence to international standards.

 

8. How to Get Started

To start with AI Toolkit, it‚Äôs necessary to set clearly defined and measurable objectives for AI agent implementation, while prioritizing Data Quality.

Find about how you can start with the implementation and get use of Multi-Model Support Architecture here: Setting Up your SAP CX AI Toolkit System | SAP Help Portal

Helpful assets: 

  • Discovery Center - AI Capabilities
  • Discovery Center - AI Estimator
  • SAP CX AI Toolkit | SAP Help Portal
  • See How AI Agents Streamline Customer Service

In the SAP Road Map Explorer you can find out what is planned for future releases of the AI Toolkit, but also what we have already upgraded in the past. 

If you would like to check what is coming to Agentic technology in Sales Cloud V2, we suggest you, visit Unleashing Agentic AI in SAP Sales Cloud V2 : Her... - SAP Community

 

9. Partnership between Humans and AI Agents

The art of the possible with AI agents in sales and service isn't just about what technology can do‚Äîit's about what humans and AI can achieve together as partners. AI Agents are ideal partners for use cases that are mentioned in the article because the time used to train and prepare is insignificant compared to time and cost savings they deliver over time.

What is important to always have on your mind? AI Agents will always need human guidance to understand urgency from customer or to sense need for different kind of assistance, no matter how much we train them. This is why humans need to master AI Mastermind and unlock the full potential of this partnership!

entry.title: Serial Number Profile : Prefix (CBC activity 103636)
entry.content:
Hello,

I am trying to set up Serial number prefix for my customer.

I have read this blog which explains how to kind of manage serial numbers number range but this model can only work if we want to have the same number ranges for ALL materials in all divisions because the reange number is related to the equipment category. Also it will only accept digits, no alphanumerical characters, special character etc...

Instead, I thought about using the Prefix field in the CBC activity 103636 which really seems dedicated to that usage:

But whether it is numerical or alphanumerical characters, the prefix won't show on the material serial numbers automatically created.

Note : this is to work with WM.

Any idea what I am doing wrong to make it work?

Many thanks,

Adrien
